BRCA1.description: BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene that helps repair damaged DNA. Pathogenic variants in BRCA1 significantly increase the risk of breast and ovarian cancer.
associated_conditions: Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome (HBOC)
BRCA1.penetrance: Up to 72% lifetime risk for breast cancer; up to 44% for ovarian cancer

pathogenic.summary: A pathogenic variant in BRCA1 has been identified. This is a significant finding that indicates an increased lifetime risk for certain cancers, particularly breast and ovarian cancer.
what_this_means: You have an inherited genetic change that increases cancer risk
This does NOT mean you have cancer or will definitely develop cancer
Risk varies between individuals - not everyone with this variant develops cancer
Early detection and prevention strategies are available
what_this_does_not_mean: This is NOT a cancer diagnosis
This does NOT mean cancer is inevitable
This does NOT mean you need immediate surgery or treatment
This does NOT affect your current health status

next_steps.title: Genetic Counseling
next_steps.description: Meet with a certified genetic counselor to discuss your personal risk assessment

next_steps.title: Enhanced Screening
next_steps.description: Discuss options like MRI screening, earlier mammograms, and CA-125 testing

next_steps.title: Family Notification
next_steps.description: Consider informing blood relatives who may also carry this variant

next_steps.title: Risk-Reduction Discussion
next_steps.description: Learn about options including increased surveillance, medications, or preventive surgery

questions_to_ask: What is my specific lifetime risk for breast and ovarian cancer based on my family history?
What screening schedule do you recommend for me?
Should I consider risk-reducing medications like tamoxifen?
What are the pros and cons of risk-reducing surgery?
How should I share this information with my family members?
Are there clinical trials I might be eligible for?

vus.summary: A Variant of Uncertain Significance (VUS) has been identified in BRCA1. This means we don't yet know if this specific genetic change affects cancer risk.
what_this_means: A genetic change was found, but its significance is unknown
This is NOT the same as a pathogenic (harmful) variant
Most VUS are eventually reclassified as benign (harmless)
Your cancer risk assessment should be based on family history, not this VUS
what_this_does_not_mean: This is NOT a positive result for a cancer gene
This does NOT increase your known cancer risk
This should NOT change your medical management
This is NOT a reason for increased surveillance beyond family history recommendations

next_steps.title: Genetic Counseling
next_steps.description: A genetic counselor can explain what VUS means for your specific situation

next_steps.title: Family History Assessment
next_steps.description: Your screening should be based on family history, not this VUS

next_steps.title: Periodic Re-evaluation
next_steps.description: Ask about variant reclassification programs that notify you if the classification changes

questions_to_ask: Should my medical care change based on this VUS?
How will I be notified if this variant is reclassified?
What does my family history suggest about my cancer risk?
Is there any research being done on this specific variant?

benign.summary: A benign variant in BRCA1 has been identified. This is a normal genetic variation that does NOT increase cancer risk.
what_this_means: This genetic change is harmless
It does not affect your cancer risk
No special action is needed based on this finding

next_steps.title: Continue Standard Care
next_steps.description: Follow age-appropriate cancer screening guidelines

BRCA2.description: BRCA2 is a tumor suppressor gene involved in DNA repair. Pathogenic variants increase risk for breast, ovarian, prostate, and pancreatic cancers.
associated_conditions: Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome (HBOC)
BRCA2.penetrance: Up to 69% lifetime risk for breast cancer; up to 17% for ovarian cancer

pathogenic.summary: A pathogenic variant in BRCA2 has been identified. This indicates an increased lifetime risk for several cancers, including breast, ovarian, prostate, and pancreatic cancer.
what_this_means: You have an inherited genetic change that increases cancer risk
BRCA2 risks are generally slightly lower than BRCA1 for ovarian cancer
Men with BRCA2 have increased prostate and breast cancer risk
Early detection and prevention strategies are available
what_this_does_not_mean: This is NOT a cancer diagnosis
This does NOT mean cancer is inevitable
This does NOT require immediate treatment decisions

next_steps.title: Genetic Counseling
next_steps.description: Discuss your personal risk assessment with a genetic counselor

next_steps.title: Enhanced Screening
next_steps.description: Discuss MRI screening, earlier mammograms, and other surveillance options

next_steps.title: Family Notification
next_steps.description: Blood relatives may also carry this variant

questions_to_ask: What is my specific cancer risk based on this variant and my family history?
What screening schedule do you recommend?
What risk-reduction options should I consider?
How do I inform my family about this result?

vus.summary: A Variant of Uncertain Significance (VUS) in BRCA2 means we cannot determine if this genetic change affects your health.
what_this_means: The significance of this variant is currently unknown
Most VUS are eventually found to be benign
Medical decisions should not be based on this VUS alone

next_steps.title: Genetic Counseling
next_steps.description: Discuss what this VUS means in your specific context

APOE.description: APOE is involved in fat metabolism and brain health. The e4 variant is associated with increased Alzheimer's disease risk, while e2 may be protective.

variants.e2/e2: May be protective against Alzheimer's; associated with type III hyperlipoproteinemia

APOE.important_context: APOE e4 is a RISK FACTOR, not a deterministic gene. Many e4 carriers never develop Alzheimer's, and many Alzheimer's patients don't have e4.

e4_carrier.summary: You carry at least one copy of the APOE e4 variant, which is associated with increased Alzheimer's disease risk. However, this is NOT a diagnosis or prediction.
what_this_means: APOE e4 is the most significant common genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer's
Having e4 does NOT mean you will develop Alzheimer's
Many people with e4 never develop dementia
Lifestyle factors can significantly influence your actual risk
what_this_does_not_mean: This is NOT a diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease
This does NOT predict when or if you will develop dementia
This does NOT mean prevention is impossible
This is NOT a reason to make major life changes based solely on this result

next_steps.title: Genetic Counseling
next_steps.description: Discuss what this means for you personally with a genetic counselor

next_steps.title: Brain-Healthy Lifestyle
next_steps.description: Exercise, diet, sleep, and cognitive engagement may reduce risk regardless of genetics

next_steps.title: Cardiovascular Health
next_steps.description: APOE e4 also affects heart health; managing cardiovascular risk factors is important

questions_to_ask: What is my actual lifetime risk considering my family history and lifestyle?
What lifestyle changes have the best evidence for reducing risk?
Should I participate in Alzheimer's prevention research?
How should I think about long-term planning?
What are my options if I notice memory changes in the future?

MTHFR.description: MTHFR is involved in processing folate (vitamin B9). Common variants (C677T, A1298C) are very frequent in the population and have been overhyped in wellness circles.
MTHFR.important_context: MTHFR variants are EXTREMELY COMMON and NOT clinically significant for most people. Be cautious of sources that overstate their importance.

any_variant.summary: MTHFR variants (like C677T or A1298C) are very common in the general population. For most people, these variants have minimal or no clinical significance.
what_this_means: MTHFR variants are found in 20-40% of the population
Most people with these variants have no health issues related to them
Standard dietary folate intake is usually sufficient
This finding is often over-interpreted in wellness/alternative medicine
what_this_does_not_mean: This does NOT mean you have a serious health condition
This does NOT require special supplements in most cases
This does NOT explain unexplained symptoms you may have
This is NOT the cause of fatigue, brain fog, or other common complaints
any_variant.caution: Be wary of practitioners who recommend expensive supplements or treatments based solely on MTHFR status. The scientific evidence does not support most of these interventions.

next_steps.title: Standard Nutrition
next_steps.description: Eat a balanced diet with adequate folate from foods like leafy greens, legumes, and fortified grains

next_steps.title: Prenatal Planning
next_steps.description: If planning pregnancy, standard prenatal vitamins with folic acid are typically sufficient

questions_to_ask: Is there any reason I specifically need methylfolate supplements?
What does my homocysteine level show? (Only relevant blood test)
Should I be concerned about this finding?

Factor V Leiden.description: Factor V Leiden is the most common inherited blood clotting disorder. It increases the risk of developing abnormal blood clots.
Factor V Leiden.inheritance: Autosomal dominant (but risk varies by copies)

heterozygous.summary: You carry one copy of the Factor V Leiden variant. This slightly increases your risk of blood clots, but most carriers never experience a clotting event.
what_this_means: Your blood clot risk is about 3-8 times higher than average
Most people with one copy never have a blood clot
Risk increases with other factors like surgery, pregnancy, or birth control pills
This is one of the most common genetic variants - about 5% of Caucasians carry it

next_steps.title: Inform Healthcare Providers
next_steps.description: Tell doctors and surgeons about this finding, especially before procedures

next_steps.title: Discuss Contraception
next_steps.description: If applicable, discuss birth control options as estrogen-containing contraceptives increase clot risk

next_steps.title: Know Warning Signs
next_steps.description: Learn the symptoms of DVT (leg pain/swelling) and pulmonary embolism (chest pain, shortness of breath)

homozygous.summary: You carry two copies of the Factor V Leiden variant. This significantly increases your blood clot risk and warrants medical attention.
what_this_means: Your blood clot risk is about 25-50 times higher than average
You should work with a hematologist for personalized guidance
Preventive measures are important, especially during high-risk situations

next_steps.title: Hematology Consultation
next_steps.description: See a blood disorder specialist for personalized management

standard_response.summary: A Variant of Uncertain Significance (VUS) means scientists haven't yet determined if this genetic change is harmful or harmless.
key_points: VUS is NOT a positive result
Most VUS are eventually reclassified as benign (harmless)
Do NOT make medical decisions based on a VUS alone
standard_response.recommendation: Discuss with a genetic counselor. Your medical care should be based on your personal and family history, not on this VUS finding.

standard_response.summary: A Likely Benign classification means this variant is probably harmless, though there's a small chance the classification could change.
key_points: Generally treated the same as benign (no action needed)
Greater than 90% certainty this is harmless

standard_response.summary: A Benign classification means this variant is a normal genetic variation and does NOT cause disease.
key_points: This is just normal human variation
